fields.field_description: final_value = value + (authority_value_coefficient * agent.attribute_level(ATTRIBUTE_AUTHORITY)
final_value = value + (subterfuge_value_coefficient * agent.attribute_level(ATTRIBUTE_SUBTERFUGE)
final_value = value + (zeal_value_coefficient * agent.attribute_level(ATTRIBUTE_ZEAL)

The proportional effectiveness of the skirmisher against the other unit.  0.5 means both units get equal attack time.  0.75 means the skirmisher gets three times as much attack time as the other unit.  Will be clamped between zero and one.

The relative speed of the skirmisher relative to the other unit at which this relative effectiveness applies.  1.0 means both units are the same speed.  2.0 means the skirmisher is twice as fast.  0.5 means the skirmisher is half the speed.

Supports capturing faction (faction), capturing subculture (subculture), subculture captured from (region_owner_subculture), region origin subculture (originating_subculture) and campaign (campaign). Note that the data is organised as "occupation option provided by group(s)", not "group provides occupation options", so a later group can never remove an option provided by an prior group.

How much we modify flaming damage, 0 is unaffected, -100 is double damage, +100 is negation
How much we modify magical damage, 0 is unaffected, -100 is double damage, +100 is negation
How much we modify physical damage, 0 is unaffected, -100 is double damage, +100 is negation
How much we modify missile damage, 0 is unaffected, -100 is double damage, +100 is negation
How much we modify all damage, 0 is unaffected, -100 is double damage, +100 is negation
How should the ai use this unit in battle?
draughts needs mounting with man_entity.
Check this to force synchronised walk, run, charge animation.
Added to a projectile's marksmanship value to determine the final accuracy of a shot. Accuracy is a percentage chance of hitting the calibration area.
Each entity carries this amount of ammo. However, artillery ammo is stored per engine - artillery crew do not carry artillery ammo.
Note that this armour does not affect visuals - this entry is for audio and game logic only.
Movement speed on campaign map.
When charging, the Charge Bonus is added to both Melee Attack and Damage, split across regular Damage and Armour Piercing Damage.
Used by several functions, e.g. AI understanding of unit, group formations.
When placing units in a map via script, use the main unit key, not land unit key.
The animation table needs to be compatible with the items on the unit.
Select the entity that the unit is made up of here. We store some unit information on an entity level, e.g. speed.
Melee Attack determines the hit chance of a unit.
A unit's Melee Defence lowers an attacker's Melee Attack, thus lowering his hit chance. Shields provide more Melee Defence. Flank and rear attacks ignore part of a unit's Melee Defence.
Base morale of the unit. The starting morale in a battle is likely to be higher, as the general and the formation grants bonuses.
Hit points are generally set in the battle entity table (e.g. 30 for infantry), but we can add some bonus HP here, saving us from creating a new battle entity entry.
This links to the mount table, where mounts are assigned an animation table and battle entity. The suffix is short for the weight of the horse, e.g. _vl for very light.
Note that the officer characters of a handler unit will not have animals.
This links to the animal table, where animals are assigned an animation table and battle entity. Animals also have some combat stats of their own.
Note that while the number of mounts is selected here, the unit size itself is set in main_units. They should always be the same, else you will get an assert.
The damage of a unit depends on its melee weapon, which can be selected here.
Select a missile weapon here. The ammo options are linked to the missile weapon, not the unit.
Default depth of the unit.
Note that this shield does not affect visuals - this entry is for audio and game logic only.
Determines how tight and orderly the formation of the unit is.
There are some hardcoded functions that check the training level.
The number of "engines", e.g. artillery pieces. The engine itself is set further right in the land_units table. The number of engines/guns does not change by unit size settings.
Select which battle personalities a unit has here.
Add engines here, e.g. artillery pieces. The amount of engines to add is set further to the left in the land_units table.
This value is only used if no spotting_and_hiding group was selected.
This value is only used if no spotting_and_hiding group was selected.
Attributes are passive abilities, i.e. special behaviour and effects that are always on and cannot be turned off.
This value is only used if no spotting_and_hiding group was selected.
This value is only used if no spotting_and_hiding group was selected.
Links to the battlefield_chariot table to define animations, models and entities of the chariot.
Typically 1, as we set up chariot land units as a single chariot and then increase the amount in the main units table.
A percentage reduction of all projectile reload speeds fire by this unit.
The formation "loose spacing" is added here, while most other formations are added through the special ability system.
Allows you to select a data set for spotting and hiding, reducing the balancing effort for all units that fit into these broader scouting sets.
This affects the range that the unit can be spotted at. Less than 1 makes it longer, greater than 1 shorter. E.g. 1.5 would increase range at which this unit is spotted at by +50%.
Amount of 'points' this unit adds to the capture point every second.
Added to a projectile's marksmanship value to determine the final accuracy of a shot. Accuracy is a percentage chance of hitting the calibration area.

Tier, only used in ui to show level of unit
High threat units override the entity threshold checks of melee reactions. If they run into or attack a unit, the unit will instantly react, even if less than 25% of their entities are affected.
Determines if the number of men / artillery pieces in this unit should be scaled with the gfx unit size setting (true) or not (false)
Full path of composite scene to use for porthole in battle (optional, if empty will just render unit from battle. Only required for special circumstances like chariots)

Base Melee Combat Potential of this unit. Must be >= 0.0 or the game will crash on startup. This value is modified (increased) by other factors such as Rank and equipped Abilities / Items. Reduced by 20% for missile cav.

Base Missile Combat Potential of this unit. Must be >= 0.0 or the game will crash on startup. This value is modified (increased) by other factors such as Rank and equipped Abilities / Items. Reduced by 20% for missile cav.

Relevant for pikes, cav refusal distances and close proximity. The latter picks between this and 1m + entity radius, whatever is longer, to determine weapon "reach". Chariot riders use this to check if enemies are within reach.

Reduces the turning of the projectile after the player stopped turning it (a bit like fake air resistance)
Cam height
Cam distance from projectile
Air resistance. In combination with gravity, launch speed, lift and tail, this gives you control over the max range of the projectile. Values around 0.002 are good for the Doomdiver.
Impact cam distance
Impact cam height
How long the impact cam shows the impact position
Inverted controls move the projectile up when moving the mouse downwards
higher values = easier to keep velocity and gain height
higher values = increase resistance against the lift
Time to look ahead to predict future position of target (intercept vs pursuit).
If target angle delta is greater than this threshold, stop homing.
Time after launch to start homing.
Multiplier to muzzle speed to get velocity correction per second.
User description.
Size of entity that will stop this projectile immediately.
Unique key.

Penetration stat. A higher number means this projectile passes through more penetration points before being stopped. Check the battle entities table to see how many penetration points a single entity has.
The icon to use in ui/battle ui/ability icons for this ability button
The icon to use in ui/battle ui/ability icons for this ability button
This is the maximum angle that the projectile can be fired at. Generally you want it high (max 90 degrees), and above 45. Except for special cases (e.g. cannon). Not used when trajectory is fixed!

This describes the speed the projectile launches at (metres per second). If it is negative, the code will calculate this value based on firing at 45 degrees, hitting at the effective range. Not used when trajectory is fixed!

Use this value to make projectiles be more / less affected by gravity. This is mainly used as a representation of wind resistance, so that projectiels can hang in the air. Negative means to use 'normal' gravity.
Number of shots in a single burst (value of 1 means no burst mode)
Determines the delay between each shot of the same burst
Mass of the projectile.
Link to projectile_homing_params table.
How much do we contribute to setting things on fire. Also, if this value is greater than 0, this is considered a flaming attack
Are we considered magical, for contextual reasons
Can this projectile target a flying unit
Elevation of fixed trajectory
If this value is positive it dictactes the maximum distance a projectile can travel before it expires
Launch beams will attempt to make the vfx match the projectiles travel, and apply a clipping plane when a projectile hits something, culling the projectiles in front
If true, the projectile will expire on impact, and will not stick into, or deflect off the object it hit
Can the projectile roll on the ground
If this flag is on, then the trail will always get displayed, regardless of the UI preference for showing projectile trails

Usually units shoot 1 hot per volley, but some animations have multiple fire points, such as multi-shot artillery units. Most of the logic isn't aware of this, so this field is for reference for those systems
If this flag is on (and the firing entity is a macro entity) the mount will fire, rather than the rider
When this is true, all fire positions in an animation will aim at the original position of the target, otherwise they will track the target position
Prefer entities nearer the centre of the target (rather than closest in firing arc)

Explosions happen when the projectile hits either the target or the ground (check that penetration is off for detonating when hitting the target).
Determines spinning behaviour of projectile while flying.
Low / High: Aims for the lowest / highest angle possible. Fixed: Always fire at max_elevation, adjusting speed of projectile only to set range.
Mainly used to limit targeting, as the actual effective range depends on velocity and angle.
Can't target units closer than the minimum_range
This is the maximum angle that the projectile can be fired at. Generally you want it high (max 89 degrees), and above 45. Except for special cases (e.g. cannon)

Used to spread out multiple projectiles fired at once, e.g. for gravel shot
Armour piercing damage, ignores armour

This will activate the explosion n metres from target. If n is greater than distance to target, then the explosion will occur instantly when the projectile is activated. To get beyond this, add a min_range to the projectile.
How much this explosion contributes towards causing ignition. Also, this determines it being flaming as a context
Is our context 'magical'
How much armour penetration damage this causes per entity hit
This is how much force is applied to determine the result of being hit, for knockbacks etc.
Fixed fuse time in s. -1 means not fixed. Use EITHER fixed fuse time or distance from target
Fixed fuse time in s. -1 means not fixed. Use EITHER fixed fuse time or distance from target

if the unit has abilities, their recharge will be changed by that amount (negative will reduce the time, positive will increase the time)
This will add morale while active, preventing routing.

values: (>= 0) - chance to spawn female character (in percent). If not set (value < 0) -> the value is read from female_character_faction_spawn_rates.
values: ("y" / "n") - the ability to "raise a force" from a settlement.
values: ("y" / "n") - access to the "Secure Promotion" action, as well as the ability to be faction and party leader.
values: ("y" / "n") - access to any and all actions listed as missions (Diplomat, Administrator, Organize Feast + the new Political Marriage, Diplomatic Marriage, Dynastic Marriage).
special trait gives females bonus to missions.
